name: Caribbean Music
description: Meta-genre covering all forms with roots in the Caribbean region.

children.name: Aleke
children.description: Derived from traditional Surinamese Maroon music, especially aukansi, features distinct faster rhythms.

children.name: Bachata
children.description: Romantic dance and accompanying music originating in the Dominican Republic, featuring arpeggiated chords in the melody.

children.name: Brukdown
children.description: Belizean Creole genre typified by the use of accordion, banjo, and a distinctive percussion section.

children.name: Bullerengue
children.description: Afro-Colombian popular genre which features a strong emphasis on rhythm and improvisation and a call-and-response format.

children.name: Calypso
children.description: Genre from Trinidad and Tobago featuring a brass section and percussion.

children.name: Caribbean Folk Music
children.description: Meta-genre that covers the different forms of Traditional Folk Music from the Caribbean.

children.name: Champeta
children.description: Colombian genre heavily influenced by the traditional music of San Basilio de Palenque as well as modern Caribbean and African sensibilities.

children.name: Cuban Music
children.description: Encompasses the wide variety of traditions from the island of Cuba.

children.name: Cumbia colombiana
children.description: Style that incorporates elements of Colombian traditional music, which includes and keeps influences from Spanish, African, and Indigenous cultures.

children.name: Dembow
children.description: Originated in the Dominican Republic during the early 1990s, featuring rapping indebted to Hip Hop and a style drawing on Dancehall, particularly the "Dem Bow" riddim.

children.name: French Caribbean Music
children.description: Music from the French Antilles (Martinique, Guadeloupe, Dominica, Saint Lucia) and from Haiti.

children.name: Gaita zuliana
children.description: Emerged in the state of Zulia in the 1950s, merging Spanish Folk Music and Venezuelan Christmas carols.

children.name: Garifuna Music
children.description: Music of the Garifuna, an Afro-Indigenous people from Central America and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.

children.name: Goombay
children.description: Bahamian music centered around the drum known as the goombay, a sort of membranophone.

children.name: Indo-Caribbean Music
children.description: Music of the Indo-Caribbean diaspora.

children.name: Jamaican Music
children.description: Regional music of Jamaica ranges from its cultural origins in traditional and religious folk of the late 19th and early 20th centuries to the international popularity of Reggae from the 1970s onwards.

children.name: Junkanoo
children.description: Highly rhythmic Bahamian style which traditionally accompanies the arts festival and street parade of the same name.

children.name: Kaseko
children.description: Surinamese popular music with roots in Surinamese Creole music, which was influenced by folk traditions of Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

children.name: Merengue
children.description: Dominican Republic dance genre that had a commercial boom at the end of the 1980s.

children.name: Palo de mayo
children.description: Upbeat music accompanying maypole dancing from the Caribbean coast of Central America.

children.name: Parang
children.description: Latin-Caribbean genre central to Trinidad and Tobago and Venezuela traditionally used for nighttime celebrations in Trinidadian towns.

children.name: Porro
children.description: Lively Hispanic American Music and dance style native to Colombia which gained popularity in the 1940s.

children.name: Soca
children.description: Upbeat, poppy and danceable style rooted in Calypso and Indo-Caribbean Music; developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s in Trinidad and Tobago.

children.name: Steel Band
children.description: Ensembles made out of steel drums that often perform Standards, Calypso, and Western Classical Music with densely rhythmic and colorful arrangements.

children.name: Tropicanibalismo
children.description: Colombian scene born in the early 2000s with the intention of reinventing Colombian coastal music, from a more current and experimental approach.

children.name: Vallenato
children.description: Accordion-led style of folk and popular music originating in Colombia's Caribbean region.
